text:
Hello, everyone. Welcome. I'm Krishna Rajagopal, MIT's
Dean for Digital Learning.

And I'm here to welcome
everyone to this joyous occasion as OpenCourseWare turns 20.

Today, we celebrate
OCW's first 20 years, and look ahead to the potential
and the plans for OCW,

and the entire ecosystem of
open educational resources that OCW sits within,
in its next 20.

The mission of OCW
since its founding was to unlock knowledge
and empower minds

by publishing materials from
virtually all MIT courses, and extend the reach of those
materials via the OER movement

which OCW played a
key role in seeding. Charles Vest, who is
the president of MIT who

launched OCW 20 years
ago, spoke at that time about how surprising and
audacious the vision of OCW

that came to him from a founding
group of MIT faculty members was.

Put all of our materials
on the internet, openly? This came as a big surprise to
President Vest 20 years ago.

One way to see how right
the faculty were back then, those founding faculty,
is to say that today,

sharing our pedagogy, our
perspective, our insights, openly via OCW is simply
unquestioned at MIT.

It's seen as just a
part of what we do. It comes from who we are.

Of course we do this. And the fact that so much
has changed in 20 years

is a sign that the
founders, the pioneers, were as right as
in fact, they were.

So, jumping ahead today,
let's look at OCW today. 2,500 courses on OCW.
Material from 2,500 courses. From 1,700 MIT instructors.

OCW is the largest .edu
YouTube channel in the world, with 2.97 million subscribers.

And over the history of
that YouTube channel, more than 2 billion minutes
of learning on that YouTube

channel. And I'll remind you that OCW
was founded long before YouTube.

And the idea that OCW would
include video in this way was something that came after
the founding, it's more recent.

And yet, here we are. What about the OCW website,
which is where it all began?

To date, 210 million
visitors to the OCW website. And just time on
the website itself,

more than a billion
minutes of learning. And really, untold
billions, we don't

know how many more
billions, of minutes of learning that OCW has
made possible, as people

use the materials
from the website. Download a problem
set, learn by doing.

As people share the
materials from that website. As people teach
their own students

using the materials
from that website. The learning that has resulted
as a consequence of OCW

is inestimable. And furthermore,
the magic of OER is that these materials morph,
and get reshaped, and shared,

and ripple outwards
in myriad ways, as educators and organizations
within the OER world

take them and make
them their own. For all of this, we, and
millions around the world,

owe our thanks to so many. Let me first thank the founding
generation, the faculty who

were there at the
beginning who had the-- created the
vision of OCW, one of whom you'll be hearing
from later today.

I also want to thank 1,700
MIT faculty and instructors who have contributed,
and continue

to contribute, their
insights from their teaching, the artifacts of their teaching,
the products of their labors,

what they've created
as they teach on campus in MIT's classrooms.

Next, I want to thank
thousands and thousands of generous supporters who
have made this all possible,

including two key foundations,
the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation, and the Andrew
W. Mellon Foundation,

without whom none of
this would have happened. I also want to thank key
corporate supporters, of whom

there are a number, including
in particular Ab Initio and MathWorks, as well as
major individual supporters,

including people like
MIT alum John Gruber, and thousands more.

And some of the supporters, many
of these supporters, in fact, are here with us today, all of
whose generosity we gratefully

acknowledge today as a
part of this celebration. And last but far from least, I
want to thank the devoted OCW

team itself. 17 devoted people who make
the magic of OCW happen.

Their work, their
continuing efforts, realizes MIT's
sustained and ongoing

institutional commitment to OCW,
for which we're also grateful.

For the institutional
commitment to OCW, this wonderful incarnation
of MIT's mission and values.

If you look at the
mission of MIT, you see creating, sharing,
and preserving knowledge. OCW does that in spades.

And then you see a
phrase in the mission that says that MIT is committed
to working with others,

to bring knowledge to bear on
the world's great challenges. As we look to the future,
now, to the evolving place

of OCW in the OER landscape,
OER is the embodiment, for OCW,

of working with others
to bring knowledge to bear on the great
challenges of the world.

We see a path, as we
look ahead, to going from the magnificent access
that OCW has already created--

access to knowledge,
access to learning, access to MIT's teaching.

Going forward, we see
a path from that access to greater equity. And the way to get
from access to equity

involves collaboration. Collaboration with educators and
OER institutions, each of whom

bring knowledge to people
whom they know well, to people in widely varying
contexts with widely

varying starting points. This is a key part of our
vision for the future.

So we will return to
the OCW of the future at the end of the hour, after
hearing from a distinguished

panel. But first, let's kick
this birthday party off with a
magnificent video that

was produced by Joe McMaster
and MIT Video Production.

In creating OCW, MIT
launched a quiet but profound educational revolution.

It unleashed the global
open-sharing movement, and helped pave the way for
the worldwide phenomenon

of open digital learning. What are two or three
words to describe
OpenCourseWare's impact? I would say knowledge and scale.
Eye-opening. Enlightening. Choose your own adventure. A whole new world.

Wow, 20 years of
MIT's OpenCourseWare. It's just amazing
to think about. We've had more than 200
million people come to OCW

and learn from the materials
that MIT is sharing.

My initial introduction
to OpenCourseWare was actually at Bunker
Hill Community College. My linear algebra
professor would give us

these weekly quizzes. We told her it was hard,
and she said, actually, this is an MIT quiz.

And I was kind of blown away
that I did some part of it. And when I inquired how
she got the quiz, she said,

oh, there's this thing
called MIT OpenCourseWare. It imparted me with
this confidence of oh,

I can do this. I can survive an MIT course. And that drove me to say,
maybe I can thrive at MIT.

OCW was the pioneer. It opened everybody's
eyes to the possibility of connecting to learners who
are in different countries,

and different situations,
different ages. We are making MIT OCW available
in universities and community

libraries which do not
have internet connection. It has encouraged me to learn,
to find out about things,

to understand and to apply. There is so much that can be
achieved by just giving people

complete, wide open
access to this knowledge that they can use
whenever, wherever.

As much as they need,
as little as they need. It takes this very kind of
privileged and elite education

that we make accessible
to our students, and opens it up to
a broader public.

The very existence of MIT's
OpenCourseWare is inspiring.

It's a shining example
for institutions of higher education around the world.

I think there's also
great value in showing the range of disciplines
that are taught at MIT,

and showing the fact that the
humanities and social sciences are as much a strength of what
MIT has to offer as the STEM

disciplines. This course that I created
is now part of the record, and is now something that
someone else can build on.

Everything is there, even the
syllabus, even the instructions of the teacher's,
thesis, assignments.

OCW is, perhaps, one of the
best things that has happened
to education Worldwide. It's like being so unselfish.

You're giving everything
of what you have, and sharing it with
the other people,

especially in developing
countries like the Philippines. OpenCourseWare quite
literally changed my life.

It gave me the education
I needed when there wasn't another place to find it.

You're giving people
the tools that will allow them to
achieve their potential.

We have real problems in the
world that need to be solved, and we need problem solvers
from every area of the planet

to work on these. We've created this powerful
foundation of free access to knowledge, and together
we'll keep growing it.

We're creating better ways
for learners and teachers to find and to use
that OCW content.

And we'll keep sharing
that vibrant reflection of the teaching and
creativity from MIT.

As we think about equity, we
think about collaborators, so that we can bring
more people, starting

Together, we're
forging new paths where everyone's contributing to
the world's growing knowledge.

And we're all using and sharing
that knowledge every day to solve the world's
great challenges.

I want OCW to attract people. So it's not just a neutral,
if you want it come get it,

I want OCW to be calling on
people to educate themselves, to empower themselves,
to build and to have

the necessary tools to do
what they think is important. And I'm hoping that, over time,
this snowball from 20 years ago

becomes an avalanche of
intellectual exchange amongst humanity.

All right, well that was
deeply inspiring for me to watch every time I see it.

And I'm really glad that we
could share that with you. Next, we're going to
have a live conversation

and are leading us
together into the future. My name is Curt Newton as
Director of OpenCourseWare.

I joined the team shortly
after it launched in 2004, and I've been director
for the last few years.

And I'm happy to introduce
now my four co-panelists, Hal

Abelson, professor
of Computer Science and Engineering, part of
the original faculty team who conceived of OpenCourseWare.

He was a very busy
guy around 2000, 2001, also helping launch things like
the Creative Commons, which

we are so glad to be partners
in this enterprise with. Mussie Demisse,
current MIT undergrad

who we were introduced
to in that video. As we heard, transferred to MIT
after studying computer science

at Bunker Hill
Community College, and we've been really
glad to work with him this year on our
advisory committee.

Anjali Sastry, senior lecturer
at Sloan School of Management and founder of MIT Sloan's
GlobalHealth Lab, where she's

been building collaborations
engaging students around the world to
improve healthcare in places like sub-Saharan
Africa and South Asia.

And last but not least, Mike
Short, Associate Professor of Nuclear Science
and Engineering.

He started as a student at MIT
right when OCW was launched. Completed his master's in 2005,
completed a doctorate in 2010,

and is now a professor
of nuclear science and engineering. Has produced a number
of courses on OCW,

including the build-your-own
Geiger counter short course, lots of inspiration out there.

So I'd like to ask
each of our panelists to take, maybe, another
minute to introduce yourself

a little more fully,
and in particular maybe if you can share a reflection
on what OCW has meant to you.

And I'd like to
start off with Hal, and then we'll
move on to Mussie. OK Curt, thanks a lot.

And, Krishna, thank you for
that wonderful introduction. Today is a wonderful
20th anniversary,

but actually it's a
triple 20th anniversary. Because there are
three initiatives that are interlinked, that all
have to do with this notion

of open sharing. OCW is, I think, the
most revolutionary.

But there's also
Creative Commons, which says, how do we
align this idea of sharing

with the technicalities
of US copyright law? And then there is DSpace
in the MIT libraries, which

is how do we take that same
vision of sharing, not just MIT

educational courses, but
MIT research publications? These all sit
together, they all join

in supporting this idea of
open sharing of knowledge and what is the right--

what's the appropriate
stance for a great world leading university
to take, in terms

of benefiting humanity through
its intellectual productions? These all build
on the internet

as a vision of sharing. And it's worth noting,
we talk about vision. There were other
initiatives 20 years ago

that had the same vision. Almost none of
them survive today.

And so the three things
that we're talking about are all there, are
all productive, and are all improving humanity.

We often talk about MIT
as a wonderful vision. The reality is that visions at
this place are a dime a dozen.

What's important is
that you carry through, and you make something
that's actually implemented and sustainable.

And when I think about what MIT
started 20 years ago, the fact that we're still here,
and still producing,

unlike so many
other initiatives, is something that makes me
enormously proud of MIT.

Thank you, Hal. Thank you for helping
us get that kicked off. Mussie.

All right. Me and OCW, I kind of wish
I knew OCW much earlier.

I'm originally from
Ethiopia, and there were times where, being in
kind of a low-resource area,

the issue is not that
you don't want to learn. It's not that you don't want
to build your capabilities.

But you really don't see the
pathways and the roads that will allow you to get there.

So, for me, what
OCW really means is, it's an opportunity for me
to accomplish the things

that I want. It's a pathway. And it's not just for me,
but it's for my brothers and sisters all over the world.
Thank you. Thank you. Anjali.

Great comments. I was thinking about my
own youth, now long ago. And I would read books
and get an escape

to the rest of the
world, from the novels and non-fiction books I read.

And now, there's OCW. You can walk through
another door, and find out all
kinds of information

that's presented
in ways that allow you to make your own path
through at the pace that

works for you as an
instructor or as a learner. I benefit a ton from
teaching with OCW in my mind,

because it encourages
me to reflect, to be conscious about
what I'm teaching.

I now write all my
syllabi, for instance, with links to
open-source content,

so that others can benefit
from it and I can share freely. I love that it
mirrors our commitment

to a physically open campus. I also have gone to
other universities

where you have to always
unlock every door, and it's pretty cool
that MIT's so open.

Not amid COVID, but
soon we will be again. And finally, when I launched
my global health work,

I went to Kenya and
met all kinds of folks. I was just learning
about the discipline.

And somebody I
met very early on, just randomly on
the street, said, I use a mirror site in Rwanda.

Thank you, thank you MIT for
sharing all this material. We use it all the time.

I didn't even know. I didn't even know there were
people all over the world who were feeling part of MIT.
So that's pretty cool. Thank you Anjali. And Mike.

Sure. Well, I'd like to say that
I'm not just a contributor, but I was also a client of OCW. I started at MIT in 2001 as a
first year, and for me it's--

I've watched OCW give back to
the world, and even to MIT, in so many more dimensions
than I could have imagined.

As a first year, I was
an example-based learner. And OpenCourseWare gave me the examples I needed to survive MIT, because
without them, I'm not sure

I would have been able to. I started off, grade-wise, kind
of at the bottom of the pack, and once I found and
used OCW, that changed.

And now, as a
faculty member, I've got the opportunity to
travel all over the world, despite not moving an
inch, in the past 20 years.

I've been able to travel
outwards, and look back inwards. And to echo something
that was said before,

the number of people around
the world that use and are thankful for OCW is incredible. I had an IAE mission
to the National University

of Mongolia, and for
many of their courses their syllabus is the
OpenCourseWare syllabus.

And to see ways that
not just students learn, and they feel amazing when
they conquer MIT problem

sets of material, but how
instructors reinterpret our material gives
me inspiration

to bring back, to make
the courses at MIT better. Thank you.

I'm so glad that we're all
able to have this conversation together, and I'd like
to invite everybody who's

watching this
session to please put your questions in the
chats, and in the places

where you can enter questions,
and those will be fed back to us, and we'll definitely
spend a few minutes at the end of the
panel sharing thoughts

on some of those questions. So I'd like to return
and ask each of you a bit

of a follow up
question, if I could. Again, starting with Hal as
part of our founding team, what

was in the water in 2001? What do you think led to
this flowering of openness
at that time? What has it led to?

So it's a little hard to
remember what 2001 was like.

This was sort of the first
kind of explosion of enthusiasm around the internet.

And Chuck Vest, president
of MIT at that time, would go around talking, and
alumni and other groups

would say to him,
there's this internet. What's MIT going to do about it?

And there was this
notion about, there's an enormous opportunity, but we
didn't really know what it was.

And then there was a whole study
we took, first with McKinsey, and then with Booz Allen, trying
to come up with something.

And this revolutionary idea,
that we should just open it up

to the world, kind of emerged,
was extremely counterintuitive, because where universities were,
in those days by and large,

was that their
courses were going to be enormous gold mines. That they were going to
sell to alumni and others,

and we did a study
at MIT and said, well, know, that's not
really going to work for MIT.

And then there was
this enormous insight, I think Dick Yue had it
when he was getting food out

of the refrigerator
at night, that said, why don't we
just give it away? And the amazing thing is that
the MIT administration took it

seriously. And really put MIT's
force behind it,

and MIT's credibility behind it. And that's really
how it happened. As I mentioned before, many of
those other places, involving

Stanford, and Princeton,
and Columbia, and all that,

don't exist anymore. The one exception is eCornell. And we had this very,
very funny thing

where MIT has been asked by some
of those organizations to join. Remember that person who was
running Fathom, which came out

came out of Columbia,
came by to MIT, trying to get MIT to join
the commercial Fathom.

And this was like
the day before we were going to announce
OpenCourseWare, and it was just
kind of funny, it

was kind of
 confidential, it was kind of funny, kind of sitting
there and saying, oh, yeah, well, you know,
about tomorrow, we're

about to take all of this stuff,
and revolutionize and make it free. But it's a little hard to
appreciate the real fervent

around the internet, and
I think we'll say later, when we talk about
the future, we're in the reflection of
that period today,

and it's something we should
be thinking about very, very hard as we think about
the climate today,

as compared to the
climate 20 years ago. Yeah, thank you. Yeah.

Let's come back
to that, for sure. I'd like to ask Mussie,
as a beneficiary of some

of that openness, what
would you like people to know about how open
education is affecting

students' lives today? What did you experience,
and what do you

see both at your community
college colleagues,

and here at MIT? So before-- OER is the
solution to the problem

of the cost of educational
resources becoming a barrier to education.

And that happens at
different levels. There's the, I'm taking a
course, I want to know more,

I want to get a more in-depth
knowledge, and I'm interested. That's one aspect that OCW
really tackles directly.

You can just go to the website,
it's in an organized manner, which, in my
personal experience,

the internet usually isn't. It's just like, hey, here's
bits and pieces of everything. The other aspect of it
is, in order for classes

to get accreditation and so on,
professors in these community colleges are almost forced
to have these textbooks

that larger organizations can-- the larger institutions,
educational institutions, use.

So what, by MIT producing
open educational resources

like this, basically
what it's saying is, it's putting its big name,
its big powerful name,

behind open educational
resources, which really gives freedom back to instructors
in these community colleges

to kind of say, hey,
there's this textbook, but MIT has kind
of validated this,

and we can kind of approach it. So, for me and my friends and
all, the basic point is this.

We're trying to
get an education. And OCW is just an easier way.

It just removes certain
cost-based barriers. Yeah.

That cost foundation has
become such a core issue

in the open education
resources movement. We hear that, Mussie, a lot.

Anjali, in your experience
trying to work globally, I'm curious how you see
open knowledge sharing

playing out and helping people
build, achieve, solutions

more rapidly, more
effectively, and to what extent is the free-ness and
the openness of it

making that happen? So almost 15 years
ago, when I started

working in global
health, I realized this is a domain in which we
are, by definition, neophytes.

MIT doesn't have a
medical school or school of public health. So I already had to collaborate
in order to just get the course

going, I set up collaborations
with Harvard Medical School, clinicians all over
the world that I could find,

who would serve as guides,
as partners, help me source and develop projects.

But the minute I
started doing that, I realized I need to share. So I am relying on others to
share with me, I need to share.

So there was a really
nice fit with OCW, It's interesting, because you
think of online, I don't know,

short videos being very kind
of procedural or instructional, but OCW can handle a
lot of complexity, too.

And I've really been
wrestling over these years with how best to present
and frame that complexity.

So I guess there's two
themes in my answer. One is I think we all
rely on many others

to fuel our learning, and
being conscious of that when you share what
you've developed

is, I think, just a really
good way to keep you honest about the
role of expertise

from all over the place. And it also allows me to honor
everybody's contributions,

because I can record
and share in OCW. And third, by kind of
archiving and building

on work year-to-year,
it's really good for me as an instructor, for my
students over the years,

to be able to see, how
has our thinking evolved? And I'll say to students, we're
going to be archiving this.

And we put student work up. So we disguise it, we
get their permission, we remove any proprietary
or confidential information,

but because we
share every year, we can generate an
amazing dialogue, not only with potential
students like Mussie,

but also with alums and
with potential partners.

We get to show our work
in a new way, which I think is really cool. Yeah. Yeah.

I think this theme of opening
up the sharing of knowledge,

the access to knowledge,
across all forms of expertise is so powerful.

I'd like to ask Mike,
maybe, to start off. Having been a student
at MIT, and watched how

this institute has evolved. What do you think about the way
that students are contributing

to this knowledge, and
colleagues around the world are contributing to this
knowledge, all together mixed

up with what the MIT
faculty are teaching? What does that indicate
to us about the power

of this movement? Sure, I'd be happy
to answer that. So in terms of how does the
mere presence of OpenCourseWare

enable students, and colleagues,
and other instructors from around the
world to contribute, just the very fact
that it exists

in this purely open and
free environment, like Hal so well said, is
the deciding factor

that just allows humanity
to share its knowledge. This, to me, is the single
best thing in education.

It's the largest thing I know of
just free knowledge access to the world. And so, in every interaction
I have, from the emails

I'm getting during the
pandemic of people saying, I've watched all your
lectures and they've kept me going and
intellectually stimulated,

to hearing how other faculty at
the schools around the country and around the world have said,
hey, I took your lectures,

and we added these
other new labs. Bring them back to MIT. This, the whole
idea of open sharing

is infectious in the
best possible way. And once you get hooked,
it's hard to stop,

which also gets at
one of the questions I saw on the chat, which is,
how do you convince faculty to participate?

I think by participating. It's the single
biggest factor to me, as somebody who has both
benefited from and contributed

to OCW, it's altruism. It's the desire for your, 
what you learned

and what you can teach to
impact humanity for the better. That's, to me, the whole
reason I get up in the morning,

and I think that's the case
for most people in the world, they want to do good. They want to see
themselves do good.

And OpenCourseWare provides
this enormous attractive force for everyone to see
a part of themselves

in this rapidly
evolving and improving open educational space.

Yeah. Yeah. Thanks. It's great to see that some
of the questions coming in, I'd like to encourage
people, again,

to keep those questions coming. I think that question
of, what would you

say to folks who are a little
unsure about participating in open sharing, they may
have some hesitations.

I'd like to open that up to
the whole panel for a moment and invite other
reflections on that.

Mussie, Anjali-- So, I would say that
the act of sharing

gets you to be
reflective in a way that I think can serve your
goals as an instructor,

and a teacher. So that's one reason to share. And the other is, to Mike's
point, it is pretty addictive.

I keep coming up with new
ideas of things to share. Like, little
experiments I've tried.

Let's put that up,
let's share that. Or reflections I have. I love the educator
version of courses

that allows you,
as the instructor, to have a kind of sidebar
conversation with the audience,

and talk through
your experience, and your philosophy. I think that's a
pretty cool feature.

And OCW has not been
afraid to do all kinds of different experiments. So I had students
a few years ago

who were from
Spanish-speaking countries and Portuguese-speaking
countries.

We tried getting-- they recorded
their experience in English, but also in their
native languages.

And that was pretty cool. We just gave that a shot. OCW was totally
willing to do it.

And we didn't actually have
that capability hard-baked into the OCW
platform at the time,

but that didn't stop you guys
from helping to figure it out. It's fun, figuring those
things out together.

Yeah. Mussie? Yeah. So I kind of want to
answer this in two ways.

The first is, to
a certain extent, it's really about
vulnerability, isn't it?

You're putting all your
content out as an institution. You're kind of saying,
this is what I do. And you'll get feedback,
whether you like it or not.

But that vulnerability
comes with a grain of, you can learn. You, as the
institution, can learn

how to do what you're
supposed to be doing better. And the other part
of it is, and I

think for a lot of
institutions, it's the fear of, well, the
value that students

pay for will be open for free. And for institutions,
that fear that, I really

want to pose the question
of, is that your only value? Is the content your only value?

And if it is, there's a
world of content coming.

Don't be Blockbuster when
Netflix came up and not adapt. Find and create value,
in education still,

but find a way that's
not just only content, and ride the wave,
as opposed to--

Yeah. Good. Great. So I think there are enormous
opportunities for MIT,

and as Mussie just
mentioned, you know, what's really MIT's value? It's not a kid sitting
down watching television.

But I wanted to make
a more general point, that when we openly share
things, for anyone, not just MIT, we're enriching
the fount that's

the source of our creativity. When we started MIT, when
we started OpenCourseWare,

Chuck Vest wrote a
nice little piece of about that where he said, he
thought the image of students

all over the world sitting and
all looking at presentations by the top faculty in the
world, that, for him, he said,

was one of his
recurring nightmares. That's not what
OpenCourseWare is about.

OpenCourseWare is enriching
the basis by which we all

do creativity, not just a couple
of top classes, but everyone. I wanted to
introduce a word that

comes from Jonathan Zittrain
at Harvard Law School called A Generative Platform. A generative platform
is where there are many,

many, many people openly
collaborating and creating new things,
